INFO.TITLE: CALI Author Page Types: An Absurdly Long Title, Typical of Some 'CALI' Lessons <§¶®©$€&"'>
INFO.CALIDESCRIPTION:
SG: Testing Resume for AutoPublish. This tests all the page types and variations supported by CALI Author. Since no single lesson uses all the features of CALI Author, this lesson does so. When desigining a test page, be sure to include a test using the maximum allowed settings.
For example, using 6 for number of multiple choice items where 6 is the max allowed. It's also a good idea to type in more than one line where you'd normally use one line such as a category heading for drag type question.
INFO.NOTES:

SG: Testing Resume for AutoPublish. This tests all the page types and variations supported by CALI Author. Since no single lesson uses all the features of CALI Author, this lesson does so. When desigining a test page, be sure to include a test using the maximum allowed settings.
For example, using 6 for number of multiple choice items where 6 is the max allowed. It's also a good idea to type in more than one line where you'd normally use one line such as a category heading for drag type question.
Approximate Completion Time: 2 hours<§¶®©$€&"'>

LI.A: Hyper Links: Note this outline topic is longer than average, but some are really this long.

BRANCH.NAME: Hyper Links: Note this outline topic is longer than average, but some are really this long.

TEXT.P: This is a book page. A book page contains text and optional media like images, sounds, video and also handles the click on image/hotspot interaction. This page contains color text, alignment and hyperlinks. White space test: word word.
It includes a sample of all HTML formatting abilities in CALI Author.
Here are some legal symbols: § ¶ © ® TM. This section symbol should stay with its nnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnumber: § 5-201. popup://IpsaThis is blue and this is red and this is black.
As a worst case Popup § 2095 scenario I also Hotspot Linclude an image from the Picture tab. Note: Superscript and subscript are used in some lessons and is not supported in Flash dynamically.
This is a new paragraph. With some blank lines after it.
Here is a bold, underline and italic word. This is bold, italic, underline and green.

Here is a jump link (Book page text and image) to the next page. This is a popup (HotSpot A). Here is a link to CALI's web site. A link to another CALI lesson (ARB01). A link to another book (CAIDES) .This is a very long hyperlink URL to test Flash bug.
I've inserted an image of groucho directly into this sentence.
And here is a 2 column x 3 row table.

TR.TD: A vegetable that was enjoyed quite readily by the English in the 16th century.

TEXT.P: Here's another big image:

QUESTION.P: My first question. This page type is by default a simple button multiple choice page. To change it, click on the Info tab, then click on the "Change type" button and you can make it any page type you want.

TEXT.P: My conclusion to the lesson.

PAGE.NEXTPAGE: Book Page 2 Text and Image Thin

TEXT.P: This page contains text and an image on the right. The next page has fullscreen image with no text.
Full screen feedback.
Image on the bottom with hotspots with C, A, L, I hot. L has no feedback. Hotspots are garish yellow for testing only! C is right, A is maybe and L is wrong. I is Info.
The next page has a full screen image with one hotspot.

MAP.AREA: C of CALI which stands for Computer because that's what we do!

TEXT.P: You clicked C
You clicked A
You clicked I
Introduction updated 2/11/2010

Voer de tekst voor deze pagina in:

This tests the different page types by using all their attributes and also using their maximum settings. In some places I add some filler text which exists solely to test what happens with large quantities of text. § ¶€©TM®

BLOCKQUOTE.P: Here's a <TAG> that should appear as a tag.

QUESTION.P: This is a 2 button question.
A hyperlink to Facts.

TR.TD:
A small perch is the first 'proper' fish that most of us caught as young anglers,
probably because it was silly enough to hang onto the bait until inexperienced hands could fumble some form of strike. Irrespective of the size of the fish, a perch is memorable because it looks the part - the large mouth, striped flanks and spikey dorsal fin could only belong to a bold predator.

Eels evoke strong emotions in many people. For some anglers, this serpent-like fish is
a bait-snaffling menace which tangles tackle; others are fascinated by eels and defend them with a passion unsurpassed by any other single-species interest group.
And scientists have still been unable to unravel all the mysteries of eels' remarkable life history.

If the salmon is the king of freshwater fish, carp can claim the title of the queen. Its
fighting capabilities and hardiness are legendary, yet the carp is also graceful and cautious, The widespread release of carp into stillwater fisheries has revolutionised coarse angling in Britain, be it for specimen-sized individuals or for much smaller and more obliging fish.

QUESTION.P: This is a 3 button question. Use Next to advance.
This is a 3 button question with a shared response.

FEEDBACK.P: And this is the shared response.

QUESTION.P: This is a multiple choice with maximum number of multiple choice items, currently 6. Each is very short. What is something not good to eat? Dirt=right. Flour=maybe (if uncooked).

DETAIL.P: Cherries. Per Intel, "The new 800 MHz bus can transmit information within the PC up to 50 percent faster than the previous version. With Hyper-Threading (HT) Technology, users can perform multiple complex tasks with greater responsiveness from their PCs. For desktop applications, these tasks include accessing instant messaging while playing a favorite online game or downloading music while manipulating digital photos. Advanced digital content creation tasks such as 3-D modeling, rendering and video editing are some of the workstation applications that benefit from these new features.

QUESTION.P: Two choice multiple choice question with shared response. What's a fruit? A hyperlink to Facts.
Here's an addition!

DETAIL.P: Yellow submarines are not for sale. A hyperlink to Facts.

SG: This tests all the page types and variations supported by CALI Author. Since no single lesson uses all the features of CALI Author, this lesson does so. When desigining a test page, be sure to include a test using the maximum allowed settings. For example, using 6 for number of multiple choice items where 6 is the max allowed. It's also a good idea to type in more than one line where you'd normally use one line such as a category heading for drag type question.

P.B: Multi set question (multiple buttons and subquestions.)

QUESTION.P: Here are 1 subquestions with 2 choices, the minimum.

PAGE.NEXTPAGE: MC Multi: 3 btn x 6 ques BIG

P.B: Multi set question (multiple buttons and subquestions.)

QUESTION.P: This is a maximum question. 3 buttons with 6 subquestions. Are the following things edible?

FEEDBACK.P: No way! (Well, maybe if you're a kid.)
Good. Dirt's not good to eat.
Depends on how old you are.
Yep. could be if cooked, isnt' if not.
Tuna is edible. Unless you're thinking it's been sitting out in the sun too long.
It's edible, though many folks would consider that a bad thing.
It's edible. Although there are reasons not to eat it.
OK. You're teeth should be in good shape.
Hmm. What kinda rock are you thinking of?

QUESTION.P: Checkbox with 2 choices and one column. Check if a fruit. There are no hints. There should also be no column header. There is only a right and wrong response.<§ ¶®©$€&"'>

DETAIL.P: Potatos. Welcome to the new Center for Computer-Assisted Legal Instruction website. CALI is a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit consortium of law schools that researches and develops computer-mediated legal instruction and supports institutions and individuals using technology in legal education.

QUESTION.P: Checkbox with 6 items and 4 columns. Has 3 hints.
Radio button with 2 items and 3 columns. No hints.

3 choices. Check everything that's a fruit. This question will give you 3 feedbacks combine into a single popup. There are 2 feedback possible for each item depending on whether you check the box or not.
If you get the answer right, you get an additional Correct message.
TODO: implement the Answer button. Not really a high priority since you always get direct feedback on whether each check was correct, unlike the other checkbox type.

DETAIL.P: Potatos. Welcome to the new Center for Computer-Assisted Legal Instruction website. CALI is a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit consortium of law schools that researches and develops computer-mediated legal instruction and supports institutions and individuals using technology in legal education.

FEEDBACK.P: Right on! Potato ain't a fruit.
Hmm, how could you forget oranges?

QUESTION.P: A slider type. How much money should each dwarf contribute to a wedding gift for Snow White? There's only one feedback with more than one slider.
Match symbol to its type. Includes 1 herring. Apostrophes are there to ensure the text fields are HTML compatible. If you see ' instead, you know they're not HTML compatible. No hints.

PAGE.ITEM: $ This is a red herring that should not be matched to either letter or number.

3. The process for exercising preemptive rights can be time consuming and costly, particularly if the corporation has a large number of shareholders and a complex capital structure. It is generally felt that directors need to have some flexibility in issuing shares to accomplish corporate purposes without being subject to the time and monetary costs associated with the exercise of preemptive rights.

RIGHT.P: Good. You matched symbols correctly. <§ ¶®©$€&"'> We skip to Question 3 on matches.

WRONG.P: Oops. You did not match the symbols correctly.

QUESTION.P: Short Answer Matches
1. Exact Match: Type apple or apples to match.
2. Contains All: Type apple pear or pear apple to match
3. Contains All in Order: Type banana cherry but not cherry banana to match
4. Contains Any: Type one or more CALI staff first names to match.
5. Does not Contain Any: Type anything except apple or pear.
TODO: Gray out GRADE button until user types something in. As it is, pressing enter or Grade without typeing something in, does nothing.
There is 1 hint.

ANSWER.P: You typed both apple and pear.
You typed banana followed by cherry (with anything in between.)
Yes, that person or persons is CALI staff.
You answer contains neither apple nor pear. (But staff name takes priority in comparisons.)

WRONG.P: Hmm, I expect apple, pear or a cali staff member first name.

HINT.P: Hmm, could be an apple or a pear.

QUESTION.P: Drag boxes maximizer 12 items in 6 categories. Classify these items. 1 herring ($ sign).

New features in Flash MX enhance the approachability, creativity, and power of Flash. Designers who require a higher level of control and integration with industry-standard design tools now have an unparalleled creative application for creating media-rich content. Powerful new features build on this creativity, giving application developers access to new capabilities that make Flash MX a robust and exciting application development environment. Developers can work with advanced scripting and debugging tools, built-in code reference, and predefined components to rapidly deploy rich Web applications.

New features in Flash MX enhance the approachability, creativity, and power of Flash. Designers who require a higher level of control and integration with industry-standard design tools now have an unparalleled creative application for creating media-rich content. Powerful new features build on this creativity, giving application developers access to new capabilities that make Flash MX a robust and exciting application development environment. Developers can work with advanced scripting and debugging tools, built-in code reference, and predefined components to rapidly deploy rich Web applications.

QUESTION.P: Essay 1. You just type. No scoring.
Essay text is saved so when user returns, his essay appears.

TODO: Since CALI Author resends the page content each time you visit a page, the internal page record holding the essay gets overwritten. The essay needs to be saved external to the page record or else the page loader needs to write the new page content into the existing record. This problem does not occur on the standalone Flash version since the entire book is in memory and pages are only loaded once.

FEEDBACK.P: Here's some feedback about your answer.

FLASHCARD.QUESTION: 1. Who's the President of the US in 2002?
2. Who invented the phonograph?
FLASHCARD.ANSWER: Thomas Edison. BTW, he did not invent the light bulb. He made it practical.
FLASHCARD.QUESTION: 3. Describe the ScrollBar component in Flash.
FLASHCARD.ANSWER: The ScrollBar component in the Flash authoring environment provides drag-and-drop functionality for adding scroll bars to dynamic and input text fields in Flash documents; it also provides a user interface for setting basic parameters. The methods of the FScrollBar component allow you to control scroll bars at runtime: you can create scroll bars, control scroll bars created in authoring, set or override basic parameters, and set additional runtime options. You do not need to use a constructor to access the methods of components. Some of the methods of the FScrollBar component are not recommended for use with scroll bars attached to text fields. See individual method entries for details. Advanced users and programmers can use the ScrollBar component with other Flash elements to create custom user interfaces. Component methods do not perform error checking for type, as do other native ActionScript objects and actions; therefore, it is recommended that you validate parameters before passing them to methods. The ScrollBar component is supported by Flash Player 6 and later versions of the Flash Player.
FLASHCARD.QUESTION: <§ ¶®©$€&"'>Question

QUESTION.P: A 3 button question with very long captions to stress test. No one should ever have captions this long, but there's no restriction imposed by CA so we check it just in case. Also test for special characters which may be URL encoded like apostrophe.

PAGE.BUTTON: No, I don't think that's right
Maybe, just maybe it's right and it's wrong

FEEDBACK.P: That's all folks! is a shared response.
Yes is right: A fake response follows:

Your answer is wrong. Jack was correct in saying that witnesses cannot testify at a hearing on a general demurrer. In Dakota (as in a number of other states) a demurrer cannot be a "speaking motion. " See Park & McFarland, p. 104.

(Courts often state that "matters outside the pleadings" cannot be presented at a hearing on a demurrer. While this phrase is a convenient way of describing the rule against speaking motions, it should be qualified by noting that only evidence about disputable adjudicative facts is excluded as "outside the pleadings." The rule against presenting "matters outside the pleadings" does NOT prohibit lawyers from presenting legal arguments, nor does it preclude the court from making policy determinations of legislative fact.)
No is wrong: A fake response follows:

Your answer is wrong. Jack was correct in saying that witnesses cannot testify at a hearing on a general demurrer. In Dakota (as in a number of other states) a demurrer cannot be a "speaking motion. " See Park & McFarland, p. 104.

(Courts often state that "matters outside the pleadings" cannot be presented at a hearing on a demurrer. While this phrase is a convenient way of describing the rule against speaking motions, it should be qualified by noting that only evidence about disputable adjudicative facts is excluded as "outside the pleadings." The rule against presenting "matters outside the pleadings" does NOT prohibit lawyers from presenting legal arguments, nor does it preclude the court from making policy determinations of legislative fact.)
Maybe is possible. A fake response follows:

Your answer is wrong. Jack was correct in saying that witnesses cannot testify at a hearing on a general demurrer. In Dakota (as in a number of other states) a demurrer cannot be a "speaking motion." See Park & McFarland, p. 104.

(Courts often state that "matters outside the pleadings" cannot be presented at a hearing on a demurrer. While this phrase is a convenient way of describing the rule against speaking motions, it should be qualified by noting that only evidence about disputable adjudicative facts is excluded as "outside the pleadings." The rule against presenting "matters outside the pleadings" does NOT prohibit lawyers from presenting legal arguments, nor does it preclude the court from making policy determinations of legislative fact.)

QUESTION.P: Pick a color. Red, Green, Blue or Cyan, Yellow.

QUESTION.P: Check box with MAX values. Max of 4 columns and 6 items (rows.)
Indicate which colors are ripe for eating (for typical American diet). E.g., green bananas wouldn't be for eating.

POSSIBLE AUTHOR OPTION: author chooses the color for each category. Normally color wouldn't matter. But in this case, the columns happen to be colors which don't match the color on screen. Please IGNORE the column colors for this question.
answer: apples: r,y,g; oranges: o; bananas: y; mangos: r,o; grapes: r,g; lettuce: r,g

QUESTION.P: Text select across paragraph boundaries. Since paragraph boundaries have different white space, this ensures that the correct text will be matched.

This is the third."

A link to another lesson. This one requires different mechanims when running from CD or from the website. For the CD we can just load the flash html page from the other lesson folder. For the website, we want to go through the authorization page (.asp). If the lesson is downloadable we need to do something else entirely.

DETAIL.P: Flour. Per Intel, "The new 800 MHz bus can transmit information within the PC up to 50 percent faster than the previous version. With Hyper-Threading (HT) Technology, users can perform multiple complex tasks with greater responsiveness from their PCs. For desktop applications, these tasks include accessing instant messaging while playing a favorite online game or downloading music while manipulating digital photos. Advanced digital content creation tasks such as 3-D modeling, rendering and video editing are some of the workstation applications that benefit from these new features.

New features in Flash MX enhance the approachability, creativity, and power of Flash. Designers who require a higher level of control and integration with industry-standard design tools now have an unparalleled creative application for creating media-rich content. Powerful new features build on this creativity, giving application developers access to new capabilities that make Flash MX a robust and exciting application development environment. Developers can work with advanced scripting and debugging tools, built-in code reference, and predefined components to rapidly deploy rich Web applications.

QUESTION.P: Multi choice set with extreme size.

DETAIL.P: And some more text. On May 21, 2003, Intel announced three Intel® Pentium® 4 processors supporting Hyper-Threading (HT) Technology and a trio of chipsets enabling faster and more feature-rich corporate and consumer PCs at mainstream price points. The new Intel Pentium 4 processors -- 2.80C, and 2.60C, and 2.40C GHz -- come equipped with HT Technology and an advanced 800 MHz system bus that allows information to flow to and from the processor more quickly.

QUESTION.P: 3 choices. Check everything that's a fruit. This question will give you 3 feedbacks combine into a single popup. There are 2 feedback possible for each item depending on whether you check the box or not.
If you get the answer right, you get an additional Correct message.
TODO: implement the Answer button. Not really a high priority since you always get direct feedback on whether each check was correct, unlike the other checkbox type.

DETAIL.P: Oranges. Welcome to the new Center for Computer-Assisted Legal Instruction website. CALI is a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit consortium of law schools that researches and develops computer-mediated legal instruction and supports institutions and individuals using technology in legal education.

Ketchup. Welcome to the new Center for Computer-Assisted Legal Instruction website. CALI is a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit consortium of law schools that researches and develops computer-mediated legal instruction and supports institutions and individuals using technology in legal education.

FEEDBACK.P: Right on! Potato ain't a fruit.
Hmm, how could you forget oranges?
Yep. Tomatos are a fruit but ketchup's got some other stuff in there.

TEXT.P: Sample text from IP03. See this big text in a popup too.

1. Chemical products used in industry, science, photography, agriculture, horticulture, forestry; artificial and synthetic resins; plastics in the form of powders, liquids or pastes, for industrial use; manners (natural and artificial); fire extinguishing compositions; tempering substances and chemical preparations for soldering; chemical substances for preserving foodstuffs; tanning substances; adhesive substances used in industry.

2. Paints, varnishes, lacquers; preservatives against rust and against deteriorations of wood; coloring matters, dyestuffs; mordants; natural resins; metals in foil and powder form for painters and decorators.
3. Bleaching preparations and other substances for laundry use; cleaning, polishing, scouring and abrasive preparations; soaps; perfumery, essential oils, cosmetics, hair lotions; dentifrices.

4. industrial oils and greases (other than oils and fats and essential oils); lubricants; dust laying and absorbing compositions; fuels (including motor spirit) and illuminants; candies, tapers, night lights and wicks.

5. Pharmaceutical, veterinary, and sanitary substances, infants' and invalids' foods; plasters, material for bandaging; material for stopping teeth, dental wax, disinfectants; preparations for killing weeds and destroying vermin.

6. Unwrought and partly wrought common metals and theft alloys; anchors, anvils, bolls, rolled and cast building materials; mils and other metallic materials for railway tracks; chains (except driving chains for vehicles); cables and wires (non electric); locksmith's work; metallic pipes and tubes; sages and cash boxes; steel balls; horseshoes; nails ad screws; other goods in non precious metal not included in other classes; ores.
7. Machines and machine tools; motors (except for land vehicles); machine couplings and belting (except for land vehicles); large size agricultural implements; incubators.
8. Hand tools and instruments; cutlery, forks, and spoons; side arms.

9. Scientific, nautical , surveying and electrical apparatus and instruments (including wireless), photographic, cinematographic, optical, weighing, measuring, signaling, checking (supervision), life-saving and teaching apparatus and instruments; coin or counterfeit apparatus; talking machines; cash registers; calculating machines; fire extinguishing apparatus.
10. Surgical, medial ,dental and veterinary instruments and apparatus (including artificial limbs, eyes, and teeth)
11. Installations for lighting, heating, steam generating, cooking, refrigerating, drying, ventilating, water supply, and sanitary purposes.
12. Vehicles; apparatus for locomotion by land, air, or water.
13. Firearms, ammunition and projectiles; explosive substances; fireworks
14. Precious metals and their alloys and goods in precious metals or coated therewith (except cutlery, forks and spoons(; jewelry, precious stones, horological and other chronometric instruments.
15. Musical instruments (other than talking machines and wireless apparatus).

16. Paper and paper articles, cardboard and cardboard articles; printed matter, newspaper and periodicals, books; bookbinding material; photographs; stationery, adhesive materials (stationer/); artists' materials; paint brushes; typewriters and office requisites (other than furniture); instructional and teaching material (other than apparatus); playing cards; printers type and cliches (stereotype).

17. Gutta percha, india rubber; balata and substitutes, articles made form these substances and not included in other classes; plastics in the form of sheets, blocks and rods, being for use in manufacture; materials for packing, stopping or insulting; asbestos, mica and their products; hose pipes (nonmetallic).

18. Leather and imitations of leather, and articles made from these material s and not included in other classes; skins, hides; trunks and traveling bags; umbrellas, parasols and walking sticks; whips, harness and saddlery.

19. Building materials, natural and artificial stone, cement, lime, motor, plaster and gravel, pipes of earthenware or cement, road making materials, asphalt, pitch and bitument; portable buildings; stone monuments; chimney pets.

20. Furniture, mirrors, picture frames, articles (not included in other classes) of wood, cork, reeds, cane, wicker, horn, bone, ivory, whalebone, shell, amber, mother-of-pearl, meerschaum, celluloid, substitutes for all these materials, or of plastics

21. Small domestic utensils and containers (not of precious metals, or coated therewith); combs and sponges; brushes (other than paint brushes); brush making materials; instruments and material for cleaning purposes, steel wool; unworked or semiworked glass (excluding glass used in building); glassware, ,porcelain and earthenware, not included in other classes.
22. Ropes, string, nets, tents, awnings, tarpaulins, sails, sacks; padding and stuffing materials (hair, kapok feathers, seaweed, etc. ); raw fibrous textile materials.
23. Yams, threads.
24. Tissues (piece goods); bed and table covers; textile articles not included in other classes.
25. Clothing, including boots, shoes and slippers.
26. Lace and embroidery, ribands and braid; buttons, press buttons, hooks and eyes, pins and needles; artificial flowers.
27. Carpets, rugs, mats and matting; linoleum's and other materials for covering existing floors; wall hangings (non textile).
28. Games and playthings; gymnastic and sporting articles ( except clothing), ornaments and decorations for Christmas trees.
29. Meats, fish, poultry and game; meat extracts, reserved, dried and cooked fruits and vegetables; jellies, jams; eggs, mil and other daily products; edible oils and fats; preserves, pickles.

30. Coffee, tea, cocoa, sugar, nee, tapioca. sago, coffee substitutes; flour and preparations made from cereals; bread, biscuits, cakes, pastry and confectionery, ices, honey, treacle; yeast, baking powder; salt, mustard, pepper, vinegar, sauces, spices; ice.

31. Agricultural, horticultural and forestry products and grains not included in other classes; living animals, fresh fruits and vegetables; seeds; rive plants and flowers; foodstuffs for animals, malt.
32. Beer, ale and porter, mineral and aerated waters and other nonalcoholic drinks; syrups and other preparations for making beverages.
33. Wines, spirits and liqueurs.
34. Tobacco, raw or manufactured; smokers' articles; matches.
35. Advertising and business.
36. Insurance and financial.
37. Construction and repair.
38. Communication.
39. Transportation and storage.
40. Material treatment.
41. Education and entertainment.
42. Miscellaneous.

DETAIL.P: Apples. Welcome to the new Center for Computer-Assisted Legal Instruction website. CALI is a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit consortium of law schools that researches and develops computer-mediated legal instruction and supports institutions and individuals using technology in legal education.

Cherries. Welcome to the new Center for Computer-Assisted Legal Instruction website. CALI is a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit consortium of law schools that researches and develops computer-mediated legal instruction and supports institutions and individuals using technology in legal education.

We are redesigning the webite to provide better service to our members and visitors. The initial phase of the redesign involved the CALI Lessons area. This was followed by the introduction of LessonLink and LessonText, 2 tools for faculty that help them use and evaluate CALI Lessons. The lastest changes include the new CALI Spotlight news area and a new color scheme and layout. The transition to the new site continues as more of the content is refreshed to reflect the new site.

This popup has a section symbol in its name.

CALI Author inserts a space after the section symbol automatically for Flash but this means a hyperlink to the page will look for one with the space while the page name doesn't have the space causing error.
Solution now is to add space to page's name.

TEXT.P: This picture is from power point and contains single pixel lines. It should be visible at smaller sizes with Smoothing.
Testing some macro expressions:
I set a variables name and amount which are displayed here: Name: %%name%%; Amount=%%amount%%. Names with Dots do NOT work.Here's a variable with _ as a test: Name.First = %%Name_First%%.
Birthday: %%birthday%% and as date %%date(birthday)%%
%%adate%%

MACROS.CODEBLOCK:
set name="Joe"
set amount=2512
set name_first = "Sammy"
set birthday= "string"
set adate= #12/31/1990#
set a="1/1"
set b="1950"
set birthday = a + "/" + b
set birthday = birthday + 390

QUESTION.P: Enter in a number from 1 to 10.

MACROS.CODEBLOCK:
event after
set numpicked =number( ResponseText)
if numpicked < 1 or numpicked >10
set result="Please choose a number from 1 to 10!"
if numpicked <1
set result = result+ " Numbers less than 1 are not acceptable"
else
set result=result+" Numbers more than 10 are unacceptable!"
endif
else
if numpicked <=5
set result = "Your number is less than or equal to 5"
else
set result ="You picked a number bigger than 5!"
endif
endif

QUESTION.P: What's your first name?

TEXT.P: Your response: %%result%%
ResponseText = %%ResponseText)%%
ResponseID = %%ResponseID)%%
Number = %%numPicked%%
Your response * 25 = %% numPicked * 25%%
Well, %%name%%, you picked %%numpicked%%. Let's move on.

MACROS.CODEBLOCK:
event after
if numpicked <=5
goto "Scripts 5 - Number Small"
else
goto "Scripts 6 - Number Big"
endif

TEXT.P: Since you picked %%numpicked%%, which is small we'll do something.
Since you picked %%numpicked%%, which is big, we'll do something.

QUESTION.P: Check box with MAX values. Max of 4 columns and 6 items (rows.)
Indicate which colors are ripe for eating (for typical American diet). E.g., green bananas wouldn't be for eating.

POSSIBLE AUTHOR OPTION: author chooses the color for each category. Normally color wouldn't matter. But in this case, the columns happen to be colors which don't match the color on screen. Please IGNORE the column colors for this question.
answer: apples: r,y,g; oranges: o; bananas: y; mangos: r,o; grapes: r,g; lettuce: r,g

DETAIL.P: In CSS, pattern matching rules determine which style rules apply to elements in the document tree. These patterns, called selectors, may range from simple element names to rich contextual patterns. If all conditions in the pattern are true for a certain element, the selector matches the element.
